    (function() {
        var htmlTag = document.getElementsByTagName("html")[0];

        if (navigator.userAgent.indexOf("MSIE 10.0") > -1) {
            htmlTag.className += ' ie10';
        }

        if (!!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./)) {
            htmlTag.className += ' ie11';
        }

        if (navigator.userAgent.indexOf("Edge") > -1) {
            htmlTag.className += ' ieEdge';
        }

        if (/(iPad|iPhone|iPod)/g.test(navigator.userAgent)) {
            htmlTag.className += ' td-md-is-ios';
        }

        var user_agent = navigator.userAgent.toLowerCase();
        if (user_agent.indexOf("android") > -1) {
            htmlTag.className += ' td-md-is-android';
        }

        if (-1 !== navigator.userAgent.indexOf('Mac OS X')) {
            htmlTag.className += ' td-md-is-os-x';
        }

        if (/chrom(e|ium)/.test(navigator.userAgent.toLowerCase())) {
            htmlTag.className += ' td-md-is-chrome';
        }

        if (-1 !== navigator.userAgent.indexOf('Firefox')) {
            htmlTag.className += ' td-md-is-firefox';
        }

        if (-1 !== navigator.userAgent.indexOf('Safari') && -1 === navigator.userAgent.indexOf('Chrome')) {
            htmlTag.className += ' td-md-is-safari';
        }

        if (-1 !== navigator.userAgent.indexOf('IEMobile')) {
            htmlTag.className += ' td-md-is-iemobile';
        }

    })();




    var tdLocalCache = {};

    (function() {
        "use strict";

        tdLocalCache = {
            data: {},
            remove: function(resource_id) {
                delete tdLocalCache.data[resource_id];
            },
            exist: function(resource_id) {
                return tdLocalCache.data.hasOwnProperty(resource_id) && tdLocalCache.data[resource_id] !== null;
            },
            get: function(resource_id) {
                return tdLocalCache.data[resource_id];
            },
            set: function(resource_id, cachedData) {
                tdLocalCache.remove(resource_id);
                tdLocalCache.data[resource_id] = cachedData;
            }
        };
    })();

                                                                                                                <span class="entry-thumb td-thumb-css" data-type="css_image" data-img-url="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/maxresdefault-5-218x150.jpg"></span>

                                                                                                    <div class="td-module-meta-info">
                                                                                                        <h3 class="entry-title td-module-title">
                                                                                                            <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/2020/10/policing-the-dark-web-tor-how-authorities-track-people-on-darknet.html" rel="bookmark" title="Policing the Dark Web (TOR): How Authorities track People on Darknet">Policing the Dark Web (TOR): How Authorities track People on Darknet</a>
                                                                                                        </h3>
                                                                                                        <div class="td-editor-date">
                                                                                                            <span class="td-author-date">
                                                                                                                <span class="td-author-info">
                                                                                                                    <span class="td-post-author-name">
                                                                                                                        <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/author/ehacking">Ehacking Staff</a>
                                                                                                                        <span>-</span>
                                                                                                                    </span>
                                                                                                                </span>
                                                                                                                <span class="td-post-date">
                                                                                                                    <time class="entry-date updated td-module-date" datetime="2020-10-09T07:59:06+00:00">October 9, 2020</time>
                                                                                                                </span>
                                                                                                                <span class="td-module-comments">
                                                                                                                    <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/2020/10/policing-the-dark-web-tor-how-authorities-track-people-on-darknet.html#respond">0</a>
                                                                                                                </span>
                                                                                                            </span>
                                                                                                        </div>
                                                                                                        <div class="td-excerpt">The darknet, especially the TOR network, can be hacked, or the information of the people using it can be extracted in the plain text....</div>
                                                                                                    </div>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                                                            </div>
                                                                                            <div class="tdb_module_header tdb_module_mm td_module_wrap td-animation-stack">
                                                                                                <div class="td-module-container td-category-pos-image">
                                                                                                    <div class="td-image-container">
                                                                                                        <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/search/label/cyber-security" class="td-post-category">Cyber Security</a>
                                                                                                        <div class="td-module-thumb">
                                                                                                            <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/2020/09/darknet-explained-what-is-dark-wed-and-what-are-the-darknet-directories.html" rel="bookmark" class="td-image-wrap" title="Darknet Explained &#8211; What is Dark wed and What are the Darknet Directories?">
                                                                                                                <span class="entry-thumb td-thumb-css" data-type="css_image" data-img-url="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/maxresdefault-3-218x150.jpg"></span>
                                                                                                                <span class="td-video-play-ico">
                                                                                                                    <i class="td-icon-video-thumb-play"></i>
                                                                                                                </span>
                                                                                                            </a>
                                                                                                        </div>
                                                                                                    </div>
                                                                                                    <div class="td-module-meta-info">
                                                                                                        <h3 class="entry-title td-module-title">
                                                                                                            <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/2020/09/darknet-explained-what-is-dark-wed-and-what-are-the-darknet-directories.html" rel="bookmark" title="Darknet Explained &#8211; What is Dark wed and What are the Darknet Directories?">Darknet Explained &#8211; What is Dark wed and What are the Darknet Directories?</a>
                                                                                                        </h3>
                                                                                                        <div class="td-editor-date">
                                                                                                            <span class="td-author-date">
                                                                                                                <span class="td-author-info">
                                                                                                                    <span class="td-post-author-name">
                                                                                                                        <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/author/irfan-shakeel">Irfan Shakeel</a>
                                                                                                                        <span>-</span>
                                                                                                                    </span>
                                                                                                                </span>
                                                                                                                <span class="td-post-date">
                                                                                                                    <time class="entry-date updated td-module-date" datetime="2020-09-22T15:37:31+00:00">September 22, 2020</time>
                                                                                                                </span>
                                                                                                                <span class="td-module-comments">
                                                                                                                    <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/2020/09/darknet-explained-what-is-dark-wed-and-what-are-the-darknet-directories.html#respond">0</a>
                                                                                                                </span>
                                                                                                            </span>
                                                                                                        </div>
                                                                                                        <div class="td-excerpt">Learn how to stay anonymous online; what is darknet and what is the difference between the VPN, TOR, WHONIX, and Tails here.</div>
                                                                                                    </div>
                                                                                                </div>
                                                                                            </div>
                                                                                            <div class="tdb_module_header tdb_module_mm td_module_wrap td-animation-stack">
                                                                                                <div class="td-module-container td-category-pos-image">
                                                                                                    <div class="td-image-container">
                                                                                                        <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/search/label/eh-tools" class="td-post-category">EH Tools</a>
                                                                                                        <div class="td-module-thumb">
                                                                                                            <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/2017/01/scan-tor-exit-relay-using-exitmap.html" rel="bookmark" class="td-image-wrap" title="Scan the TOR Exit Relay using Exitmap">
                                                                                                                <span class="entry-thumb td-thumb-css" data-type="css_image" data-img-url="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Tor-exit-node-attack-1-218x150.png"></span>
                                                                                                            </a>
                                                                                                        </div>
                                                                                                    </div>
                                                                                                    <div class="td-module-meta-info">
                                                                                                        <h3 class="entry-title td-module-title">
                                                                                                            <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/2017/01/scan-tor-exit-relay-using-exitmap.html" rel="bookmark" title="Scan the TOR Exit Relay using Exitmap">Scan the TOR Exit Relay using Exitmap</a>
                                                                                                        </h3>
                                                                                                        <div class="td-editor-date">
                                                                                                            <span class="td-author-date">
                                                                                                                <span class="td-author-info">
                                                                                                                    <span class="td-post-author-name">
                                                                                                                        <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/author/irfan-shakeel">Irfan Shakeel</a>
                                                                                                                        <span>-</span>
                                                                                                                    </span>
                                                                                                                </span>
                                                                                                                <span class="td-post-date">
                                                                                                                    <time class="entry-date updated td-module-date" datetime="2017-01-10T09:38:00+00:00">January 10, 2017</time>
                                                                                                                </span>
                                                                                                                <span class="td-module-comments">
                                                                                                                    <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/2017/01/scan-tor-exit-relay-using-exitmap.html#respond">0</a>
                                                                                                                </span>
                                                                                                            </span>
                                                                                                        </div>
                                                                                                        <div class="td-excerpt">
                                                                                                        Exitmap is a fast and modular Python-based scanner for&nbsp;Tor&nbsp;exit relays. Exitmap modules implement tasks that are run over (a subset of) all exit relays....</div>
                                                                                                    </div>
                                                                                                </div>

                                                                                        <h3 class="entry-title td-module-title">
                                                                                            <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/2017/01/scan-tor-exit-relay-using-exitmap.html" rel="bookmark" title="Scan the TOR Exit Relay using Exitmap">Scan the TOR Exit Relay using Exitmap</a>
                                                                                        </h3>
                                                                                        <div class="td-editor-date">
                                                                                            <span class="td-author-date">
                                                                                                <span class="td-author-info">
                                                                                                    <span class="td-post-author-name">
                                                                                                        <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/author/irfan-shakeel">Irfan Shakeel</a>
                                                                                                        <span>-</span>
                                                                                                    </span>
                                                                                                </span>
                                                                                                <span class="td-post-date">
                                                                                                    <time class="entry-date updated td-module-date" datetime="2017-01-10T09:38:00+00:00">January 10, 2017</time>
                                                                                                </span>
                                                                                                <span class="td-module-comments">
                                                                                                    <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/2017/01/scan-tor-exit-relay-using-exitmap.html#respond">0</a>
                                                                                                </span>
                                                                                            </span>
                                                                                        </div>
                                                                                        <div class="td-excerpt">
                                                                                        Exitmap is a fast and modular Python-based scanner for&nbsp;Tor&nbsp;exit relays. Exitmap modules implement tasks that are run over (a subset of) all exit relays....</div>
                                                                                    </div>
                                                                                </div>

                                                    <div class="tdb-block-inner td-fix-index">
                                                        <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/How-To-Find-Hidden-Web-Directories-Using-Dirsearch-1.jpg" data-caption="">
                                                            <img width="550" height="340" class="entry-thumb td-modal-image" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/How-To-Find-Hidden-Web-Directories-Using-Dirsearch-1.jpg" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/How-To-Find-Hidden-Web-Directories-Using-Dirsearch-1.jpg 550w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/How-To-Find-Hidden-Web-Directories-Using-Dirsearch-1-300x185.jpg 300w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/How-To-Find-Hidden-Web-Directories-Using-Dirsearch-1-356x220.jpg 356w" sizes="(max-width: 550px) 100vw, 550px" alt="How To Find Hidden Web Directories Using Dirsearch" title="How-To-Find-Hidden-Web-Directories-Using-Dirsearch"/>
                                                        </a>
                                                    </div>
                                                </div>
                                                <div class="td_block_wrap tdb_single_content tdi_94_33c td-pb-border-top td_block_template_1 td-post-content tagdiv-type" data-td-block-uid="tdi_94_33c">
                                                    <style>
                                                    /* custom css */
                                                    .tdi_94_33c, .tdi_94_33c > p {
                                                        font-size: 16px !important;
                                                    }

                                                    .tdi_94_33c, .tdi_94_33c p {
                                                        color: #2b2d41;
                                                    }

                                                    .tdi_94_33c h1, .tdi_94_33c h2, .tdi_94_33c h3, .tdi_94_33c h4, .tdi_94_33c h5, .tdi_94_33c h6 {
                                                        color: #333333;
                                                    }

                                                    .tdi_94_33c .page-nav a, .tdi_94_33c .page-nav span {
                                                        color: #2b2d41;
                                                    }
                                                    </style>
                                                    <div class="tdb-block-inner td-fix-index">
                                                        <p>When a security analyst performing website penetration testing the initial step should be finding hidden directories of a vulnerable website.</p>
                                                        <p>These hidden web directories are essential because they can give useful information i.e. potential attack vectors that would not be visible on the public facing website.</p>
                                                        <p>One of the ways to achieve this is by attempting brute-forcing site structure that includes directories and files in websites and for that, you have to choose a powerful tool.</p>
                                                        <p>Although there are many tools available used to perform site brute-forcing includes Dirbuster or Dirb but these have their own limitation such as Dirbuster only offers GUI interface that is not feasible all the time and Dirb does not include multithreading feature.</p>
                                                        <p>The most popular choice among penetration testers for website brute-forcing is Dirsearch.</p>
                                                        <p>Dirsearch, written in python is a command-line website directory scanner. It has a lot of features making it the complete winner in terms of performance:</p>
                                                        <ol>
                                                            <li>It includes Multithreading, making it faster than any other site scanner tool</li>
                                                            <li>It performs Recursive brute-forcing</li>
                                                            <li>It has HTTP proxy support</li>
                                                            <li>Dirsearch effectively detects invalid web pages</li>
                                                            <li>It has User agent randomization and Batch processing</li>
                                                            <li>Supports Request delaying</li>
                                                        </ol>
                                                        <p>This tool can be run on any operating system (Windows, Linux, mac) making it more compatible and simpler, yet a powerful tool.</p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            In this setup we will be using Kali Linux as an attacking machine and 
                                                            <a href="http://www.dvwa.co.uk/">DVWA</a>
                                                            on
                                                            <a href="https://metasploit.help.rapid7.com/docs/metasploitable-2">Metasploitable 2</a>
                                                            as the target.
                                                        </p>
                                                        <div id="ez-toc-container" class="ez-toc-v2_0_17 counter-hierarchy counter-decimal ez-toc-grey">
                                                            <div class="ez-toc-title-container">
                                                                <p class="ez-toc-title">Table of Contents</p>
                                                                <span class="ez-toc-title-toggle">
                                                                    <a class="ez-toc-pull-right ez-toc-btn ez-toc-btn-xs ez-toc-btn-default ez-toc-toggle" style="display: none;">
                                                                        <i class="ez-toc-glyphicon ez-toc-icon-toggle"></i>
                                                                    </a>
                                                                </span>
                                                            </div>
                                                            <nav>
                                                                <ul class="ez-toc-list ez-toc-list-level-1">
                                                                    <li class="ez-toc-page-1 ez-toc-heading-level-2">
                                                                        <a class="ez-toc-link ez-toc-heading-1" href="#Install_Dirsearch" title="Install Dirsearch">Install Dirsearch</a>
                                                                    </li>
                                                                    <li class="ez-toc-page-1 ez-toc-heading-level-2">
                                                                        <a class="ez-toc-link ez-toc-heading-2" href="#Configuring_the_Tool" title="Configuring the Tool">Configuring the Tool</a>
                                                                    </li>
                                                                    <li class="ez-toc-page-1 ez-toc-heading-level-2">
                                                                        <a class="ez-toc-link ez-toc-heading-3" href="#Site_Scanning_Using_Dirsearch" title="Site Scanning Using Dirsearch">Site Scanning Using Dirsearch</a>
                                                                    </li>
                                                                </ul>
                                                            </nav>
                                                        </div>
                                                        <h2>
                                                            <span class="ez-toc-section" id="Install_Dirsearch"></span>
                                                            <strong>Install Dirsearch</strong>
                                                            <span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span>
                                                        </h2>
                                                        <p>
                                                            You need to install Dirsearch in your 
                                                            <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/2017/02/configuring-kali-linux-in-aws-cloud.html">Kali Linux</a>
                                                             attacking machine. First update all the repositories from the command 
                                                            <em># apt-get update</em>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            After that install Dirsearch from Github by using the link: 
                                                            <a href="https://github.com/maurosoria/dirsearch">
                                                                <em>https://github.com/maurosoria/dirsearch</em>
                                                            </a>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>Type command:</p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <em># git clone </em>
                                                            <a href="https://github.com/maurosoria/dirsearch">
                                                                <em>https://github.com/maurosoria/dirsearch</em>
                                                            </a>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5024 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture1.png" alt="to install Dirsearch in your Kali Linux attacking machine" width="1066" height="289" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture1.png 1066w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture1-300x81.png 300w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture1-1024x278.png 1024w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture1-768x208.png 768w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture1-696x189.png 696w" sizes="(max-width: 1066px) 100vw, 1066px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>After successfully installing the tool, change the root directory into Dirsearch.</p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <em># cd dirsearch/</em>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5025 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture2.png" alt="to install Dirsearch in your Kali Linux attacking machine" width="643" height="109" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture2.png 643w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture2-300x51.png 300w" sizes="(max-width: 643px) 100vw, 643px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>Type ls to see the content under Dirsearch directoy.</p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="alignnone wp-image-5026 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture3.png" alt="to install Dirsearch in your Kali Linux attacking machine" width="1108" height="77" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture3.png 1108w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture3-300x21.png 300w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture3-1024x71.png 1024w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture3-768x53.png 768w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture3-696x48.png 696w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture3-1068x74.png 1068w" sizes="(max-width: 1108px) 100vw, 1108px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>You can see there is a configuration file and a python file named dirsearch.py which we are going to execute.</p>
                                                        <h2>
                                                            <span class="ez-toc-section" id="Configuring_the_Tool"></span>
                                                            <strong>Configuring the Tool</strong>
                                                            <span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span>
                                                        </h2>
                                                        <p>Next step will be configuring the Dirsearch. You can do it in three ways.</p>
                                                        <p>As this dirsearch.py file needs python 3 to execute correctly, just simply run it with python.</p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <em># python3 dirsearch.py</em>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5027 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture4.png" alt="configuring the Dirsearch" width="577" height="94" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture4.png 577w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture4-300x49.png 300w" sizes="(max-width: 577px) 100vw, 577px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            It gives a usage example, stating we need to specify a
                                                            <a href="https://null-byte.wonderhowto.com/how-to/hacking-web-apps/">valid URL</a>
                                                            .
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>The second way to run Dirsearch is to run it with Bash. Type ls -la to give us the permissions of everything in this directory.</p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5028 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture5.png" alt="configuring the Dirsearch" width="706" height="433" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture5.png 706w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture5-300x184.png 300w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture5-696x427.png 696w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture5-685x420.png 685w" sizes="(max-width: 706px) 100vw, 706px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>As we can see from above that this tool is executable, now run it using the dot-slash.</p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <em># ./dirsearch.py</em>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5029 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture6.png" alt="configuring the Dirsearch" width="556" height="94" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture6.png 556w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture6-300x51.png 300w" sizes="(max-width: 556px) 100vw, 556px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            The third and the easiest way to run Dirsearch is by creating a
                                                            <a href="https://null-byte.wonderhowto.com/how-to/get-root-filesystem-access-via-samba-symlink-traversal-0198509/">symbolic link</a>
                                                            in the
                                                            <strong>/bin</strong>
                                                            directory as this will permit us to run this tool not only with the directory cloned from GitHub but anywhere in the prompt.
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            Change into the bin directory and create a symbolic link naming it dirsearch by using the
                                                            <strong>ln -s</strong>
                                                            command.
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <em># ln -s </em>
                                                            <em>ln -s ~/dirsearch/dirsearch.py dirsearch</em>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5030 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture7.png" alt="configuring the Dirsearch" width="728" height="66" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture7.png 728w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture7-300x27.png 300w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture7-696x63.png 696w" sizes="(max-width: 728px) 100vw, 728px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <h2>
                                                            <span class="ez-toc-section" id="Site_Scanning_Using_Dirsearch"></span>
                                                            <strong>Site Scanning Using Dirsearch</strong>
                                                            <span class="ez-toc-section-end"></span>
                                                        </h2>
                                                        <p>As we have created the symbolic link, just type dirsearch in any directory to execute.</p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5031 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture8.png" alt="Site Scanning Using Dirsearch" width="781" height="125" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture8.png 781w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture8-300x48.png 300w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture8-768x123.png 768w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture8-696x111.png 696w" sizes="(max-width: 781px) 100vw, 781px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>Use the flag -h with the dirsearch to get full help menu that will show aton of options and potential configuration settings.</p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5032 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture9.png" alt="Site Scanning Using Dirsearch" width="975" height="614" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture9.png 975w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture9-300x189.png 300w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture9-768x484.png 768w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture9-696x438.png 696w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture9-667x420.png 667w" sizes="(max-width: 975px) 100vw, 975px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5033 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture10.png" alt="Site Scanning Using Dirsearch" width="975" height="1012" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture10.png 975w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture10-289x300.png 289w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture10-768x797.png 768w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture10-696x722.png 696w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture10-405x420.png 405w" sizes="(max-width: 975px) 100vw, 975px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            So now for searching the site it needs a valid targets URL and a file extension to run. You can specify a valid URL with the
                                                            <strong>-u</strong>
                                                            flag, and a file extension to search for with the
                                                            <strong>-e</strong>
                                                            flag.
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>In our case we will give it the URL of our DVWA on Metasploitable2 machine.</p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <em># dirsearch -u http://192.168.0.102/dvwa -e php</em>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5034 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture11.png" alt="Site Scanning Using Dirsearch" width="900" height="1005" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture11.png 900w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture11-269x300.png 269w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture11-768x858.png 768w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture11-696x777.png 696w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture11-376x420.png 376w" sizes="(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5035 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture12.png" alt="Site Scanning Using Dirsearch" width="975" height="1028" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture12.png 975w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture12-285x300.png 285w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture12-971x1024.png 971w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture12-768x810.png 768w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture12-696x734.png 696w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture12-398x420.png 398w" sizes="(max-width: 975px) 100vw, 975px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            This showing us a lot of information regarding the extensions, HTTP methods in use, number of threads, and size of the current
                                                            <a href="https://null-byte.wonderhowto.com/how-to/hack-like-pro-crack-passwords-part-4-creating-custom-wordlist-with-crunch-0156817/">wordlist</a>
                                                            . After that it starts to dig into the directories and returns with its findings that includes the status code, size, and directory name.
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>If you want to exclude certain HTTP status codes use -x flag.</p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <em># dirsearch -u </em>
                                                            <a href="http://192.168.0.102/dvwa" class="broken_link">
                                                                <em>http://192.168.0.102/dvwa</em>
                                                            </a>
                                                            <em> -e php -x 403</em>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5036 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture13.png" alt="Site Scanning Using Dirsearch" width="975" height="975" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture13.png 975w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture13-300x300.png 300w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture13-150x150.png 150w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture13-768x768.png 768w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture13-696x696.png 696w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture13-420x420.png 420w" sizes="(max-width: 975px) 100vw, 975px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5037 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture14.png" alt="Site Scanning Using Dirsearch" width="758" height="472" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture14.png 758w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture14-300x187.png 300w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture14-696x433.png 696w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture14-674x420.png 674w" sizes="(max-width: 758px) 100vw, 758px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>Here we are excluding all the 403 codes by specifying after -x flag. It leads us to get what we required, making it cleaner and simpler.</p>
                                                        <p>Also, you can use -w flag to use a wordlist of your choice.</p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <em># dirsearch -u http://192.168.0.102/dvwa -e php -x 403,301,302 -w /usr/share/wordlists/wfuzz/general/common.txt</em>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5038 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture15.png" alt="Site Scanning Using Dirsearch" width="975" height="279" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture15.png 975w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture15-300x86.png 300w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture15-768x220.png 768w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture15-696x199.png 696w" sizes="(max-width: 975px) 100vw, 975px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>You can see it does not find a large pool of results with this mentioned wordlist because the size is smaller.</p>
                                                        <p>Now coming to its best feature i.e. performing recursive directory scanning. Use -r flag to run the recursive search.</p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <em># dirsearch -u </em>
                                                            <a href="http://192.168.0.102/dvwa" class="broken_link">
                                                                <em>http://192.168.0.102/dvwa</em>
                                                            </a>
                                                            <em> -e php -x 403,301,302 -r</em>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5039 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture16.png" alt="Site Scanning Using Dirsearch" width="975" height="806" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture16.png 975w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture16-300x248.png 300w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture16-768x635.png 768w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture16-696x575.png 696w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture16-508x420.png 508w" sizes="(max-width: 975px) 100vw, 975px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5040 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture17.png" alt="Site Scanning Using Dirsearch" width="697" height="309" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture17.png 697w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture17-300x133.png 300w" sizes="(max-width: 697px) 100vw, 697px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>Now see there is an additional entry of Recursive Level. On completing the initial scan this will go back and starts scanning each directory it found recursively, in this case it starts config/ then docs/ and so on.</p>
                                                        <p>While scanning if you want to exit the scan parse e from keyboard. To continue it from the point you have stopped, parse c. Parse n to move to the next directory. These steps will let you have a control over the results as recursive scanning is a time-consuming process.</p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            If you want to set the recursion level to a deeper value, you can use the
                                                            <strong>-R</strong>
                                                            flag and a value of how many levels deep you want to dig.
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <em># dirsearch -u </em>
                                                            <a href="http://192.168.0.102/dvwa" class="broken_link">
                                                                <em>http://192.168.0.102/dvwa</em>
                                                            </a>
                                                            <em> -e php -x 403,301,302 -r -R 3</em>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5041 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture20.png" alt="Site Scanning Using Dirsearch" width="975" height="767" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture20.png 975w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture20-300x236.png 300w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture20-768x604.png 768w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture20-696x548.png 696w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture20-534x420.png 534w" sizes="(max-width: 975px) 100vw, 975px"/>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <img loading="lazy" class="aligncenter wp-image-5042 size-full" src="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture21.png" alt="Site Scanning Using Dirsearch" width="709" height="313" srcset="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture21.png 709w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture21-300x132.png 300w, https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Picture21-696x307.png 696w" sizes="(max-width: 709px) 100vw, 709px"/>
                                                            So, you can see this starts scanning the /administrator directory which is obviously could not be found on the top level.
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>
                                                            <strong>Conclusion</strong>
                                                        </p>
                                                        <p>This article demonstrates how to use an effective web directory brute-forcing tool Dirsearch to scan and search hidden web directories which may not be visible to a user. This is very a very first task in penetration tasting and Dirsearch do this job much faster than the traditional Dirbuster and Dirb.</p>
                                                    </div>
                                                </div>

                                                    <div class="td-block-title-wrap">
                                                        <h4 class="block-title">
                                                            <span>RELATED ARTICLES</span>
                                                        </h4>

                                                    <div id=tdi_102_f5f class="td_block_inner tdb-block-inner td-fix-index">
                                                        <div class="tdb_module_related td_module_wrap td-animation-stack">
                                                            <div class="td-module-container td-category-pos-image">
                                                                <div class="td-image-container">
                                                                    <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/search/label/academy" class="td-post-category">Academy</a>
                                                                    <div class="td-module-thumb">
                                                                        <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/2022/08/what-makes-ics-ot-infrastructure-vulnerable.html" rel="bookmark" class="td-image-wrap" title="What Makes ICS/OT Infrastructure Vulnerable?">
                                                                            <span class="entry-thumb td-thumb-css" data-type="css_image" data-img-url="https://www.ehacking.net/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/What-Makes-ICS-OT-Infrastructure-Vulnerable.2-218x150.jpg"></span>
                                                                        </a>

                                                                <div class="td-module-meta-info">
                                                                    <h3 class="entry-title td-module-title">

                                                                    <div class="td-excerpt">Infrastructure security for operational technologies (OT) and industrial control systems (ICS) varies from IT security in several ways, with the inverse confidentiality, integrity, and...</div>
                                                                    <div class="td-read-more">
                                                                        <a href="https://www.ehacking.net/2022/08/what-makes-ics-ot-infrastructure-vulnerable.html">Read more</a>
                                                                    </div>
                                                                </div>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>

                                                                    </h3>

                                                                    Operational technology (OT) is a technology that primarily monitors and controls physical operations. It can automate and control machines,...</div>

        tweet_share.href = "https://twitter.com/share?url=" + encodeURIComponent(location.href);
        linkedin_share.href = "https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=" + encodeURIComponent(location.href);
        reddit_share.href = "https://reddit.com/submit?url=" + encodeURIComponent(location.href);

    }

    jQuery(window).load(function() {
        var block = jQuery('.tdi_93_7f3'),
            blockClass = '.tdi_93_7f3',
            blockInner = block.find('.tdb-block-inner'),
            blockOffsetLeft;

        if (block.find('audio').length > 0) {
            jQuery(blockClass + ' audio').mediaelementplayer();
        }

        if (block.hasClass('tdb-sfi-stretch')) {
            jQuery(window).resize(function() {
                blockOffsetLeft = block.offset().left;

                if (block.hasClass('tdb-sfi-stretch-left')) {
                    blockInner.css('margin-left', -blockOffsetLeft + 'px');
                } else {
                    blockInner.css('margin-right', -(jQuery(window).width() - (blockOffsetLeft + block.outerWidth())) + 'px');
                }
            });
            jQuery(window).resize();
        }

        setTimeout(function() {
            block.css('opacity', 1);
        }, 500);
    });
    </script>

</body>
</html>
